factoid: Pierre is the narrator.
An old wounded soldier with a bandaged arm was following the cart on foot.
The old wounded soldier caught hold of the cart with his sound hand.
The old wounded soldier turned to look at Pierre.
The old wounded soldier asked Pierre if they would be set down or taken to Moscow.
Pierre was deep in thought and did not hear the question.
Pierre was looking at the cavalry regiment that had met the convoy of wounded.
Pierre was looking at the cart by which he was standing.
The cart contained two wounded men sitting and one lying.
One of the wounded men sitting in the cart had probably been wounded in the cheek.
The wounded man’s whole head was wrapped in rags.
The wounded man’s one cheek was swollen to the size of a baby's head.
The wounded man’s nose and mouth were twisted to one side.
The soldier with the swollen cheek was looking at the cathedral and crossing himself.
The young lad, a fair‑haired recruit, looked at Pierre kindly with a fixed smile.
The third wounded man lay prone so his face was not visible.
The cavalry singers were passing close by.
The cavalry singers sang the song ‘Ah lost, quite lost… is my head so keen, Living in a foreign land…’.
The cavalry singers sang their soldiers’ dance song.
The metallic sound of bells reverberated high above.
The hot rays of the sun bathed the top of the opposite slope.
The area beneath the slope by the cart with the wounded was damp, somber, and sad.
The soldier with the swollen cheek looked angrily at the cavalry singers.
The soldier with the swollen cheek muttered ‘Oh, the coxcombs!’ reproachfully.
The soldier with the swollen cheek said, ‘It’s not the soldiers only, but I’ve seen peasants today, too.’
The soldier with the swollen cheek said, ‘The peasants—even they have to go.’
The soldier with the swollen cheek addressed Pierre with a sad smile.
The soldier with the swollen cheek said, ‘No distinctions made nowadays.’
The soldier with the swollen cheek said, ‘They want the whole nation to fall on them—in a word, it’s Moscow!’
The soldier with the swollen cheek said, ‘They want to make an end of it.’
Pierre understood the soldier’s words and nodded approval.
The road was clear again.
Pierre descended the hill.
Pierre drove on.
Pierre looked to either side of the road for familiar faces.
Pierre saw only unfamiliar faces of various military men of different branches of the service.
The military men looked with astonishment at Pierre’s white hat and green tail coat.
Pierre had gone nearly three miles.
Pierre met an acquaintance.
Pierre addressed the acquaintance eagerly.
The acquaintance was one of the head army doctors.
The head army doctor was driving toward Pierre in a covered gig.
The head army doctor was sitting beside a young surgeon.
When the head army doctor recognized Pierre, he told the Cossack driver to pull up.
The head army doctor asked Pierre, ‘Count! Your excellency, how come you to be here?’
The head army doctor said, ‘Well, you know, I wanted to see…’
The head army doctor said, ‘Yes, yes, there will be something to see.’
Pierre got out of the gig.
Pierre talked to the doctor.
Pierre explained his intention of taking part in a battle.
The doctor advised Pierre to apply directly to Kutúzov.
The doctor said, ‘Why should you be God knows where out of sight, during the battle?’
The doctor said, ‘Anyhow his Serene Highness knows you and will receive you graciously. That’s what you must do.’
The doctor seemed tired and in a hurry.
Pierre asked the doctor where their position is exactly.
The doctor repeated the question, ‘The position?’
The doctor said, ‘Well, that’s not my line.’
The doctor said, ‘Drive past Tatárinova, a lot of digging is going on there.’
The doctor said, ‘Go up the hillock and you’ll see.’
The doctor asked, ‘Can one see from there? If you would…’
The doctor interrupted Pierre and moved toward his gig.
The doctor said, ‘I would go with you but on my honor I’m up to here.’
The doctor pointed to his throat.
The doctor said, ‘I’m galloping to the commander of the corps.’
The doctor said, ‘There’ll be a battle tomorrow.’
The doctor said, ‘Out of an army of a hundred thousand we must expect at least twenty thousand wounded.’
The doctor said, ‘We haven’t stretchers, or bunks, or dressers, or doctors enough for six thousand.’
The doctor said, ‘We have ten thousand carts, but we need other things as well.’
The doctor said, ‘We must manage as best we can.’
